comments.raw_text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/5.0
Build ID: 20110708030800

Steps to reproduce:

when page contain setTimeout or setTimeinterval loops, Firefox performance is much worse than other mainstream browser on CPU usage.
I don't know this is the reason why tuned inactive tab min timeout in Bug 633421 and Bug 652472... It seems like a kind of evade...

all tests data is in my Athlon 64 3200+ 2.0Ghz machine

1. a simple test of example of W3C, seting the inteval from 1000ms to 10ms
http://www.w3schools.com/js/tryit.asp?filename=tryjs_timing_infinite
Firefox 8.0a1 took more than 25% cpu usage on average.
Opera 11.05 about 5%
Chrome 13dev about 10%

2. in a more heavy load setTimeout() page, for example:
http://zhidao.baidu.com/question/289798517.html
when focus is in the textarea.
Firefox drain my CPU, seriously lag, while IE, Opera, and Chrome are all in normal CPU usage.


Actual results:

lag, slow reaction both firefox and the OS
comments.creator: dindog@163.com

comments.text:
Created attachment 557079
clock refresh it time with setTimeout 10ms

comments.creator: dindog@163.com
comments.author: dindog@163.com
comments.text:
No improve after TI landed. And here is another testcase with minor change from W3C school. (time-out: 500ms-> 10ms)
http://www.w3schools.com/JS/tryit.asp?filename=tryjs_timing_clock

the data below test in an Athlon X2 240, 2.4GHz Machine:
Chrome 13.0.782, CPU usage 0-1%

Firefox 9 nightly, 10-26%(TI landed) in foreground, 1%-2% in background
Firefox 7 beta2, 10-26%

Tab in background has lower CPU usage is because of Bug633421.

This bug should fix, it lags single core CPU severe.
